title: Girl, 15, killed herself after being kidnapped and sold to sex traffickers
text:
Leticia ‘Letty’ Serrano took her own life after being rescued from sex traffickers (Picture: Fox News)

A 15-year-old girl killed herself after she had been kidnapped and sold to sex traffickers, her family said.

Leticia ‘Letty’ Serrano, 15, died in her father’s arms on Saturday at her home in Houston, Texas – two years after she was rescued from a sex trafficking ring.

Her father, Mariano Serrano, said that her daughter was unable to get over being separated from the man responsible for trafficking her.

Mariano told Fox 26: ‘She wanted to be with him. But, she also didn’t want to hurt her family.’

Letty’s trafficker reportedly took her near Marshall Middle School in North Houston in 2017. Her parents searched for her for days, but came up empty handed.

Cythia Rivera, Letty’s godmother, said: ‘We were unable to locate her and call (the Houston Police Department) and have this animal arrested.’

Letty was released by her abductor days later – but she then ran away from home twice to be with him. Her family said they believe the trafficker worked with other men who drugged her and moved her around, selling her for sex.

‘She was a good student, good grades, quiet, kind of a loner, and her brother had just passed. She was a perfect target for them,’ Rivera said.

Rivera said Letty was trafficked in filthy, drug-filled abandoned houses – which is where her family reportedly found her.

Letty was taken near Marshall Middle School when she was 13-year-old. She was found later in an abandoned drug den (Picture: ABC 13)

‘(There were) mattresses, little girls’ bras, chemicals they used to mix the drugs with,’ Rivera said, speaking of the house they found Letty in.

Now the family struggles with the tragedy of Letty’s death without a scrap of closure because her captor has not been caught.

Mariano said: ‘I want to see him in court. I want to tell him it’s his fault my daughter is dead. ‘

Commander of the Houston Police Vice Division Jim Dale said he has learned of Letty’s death and ‘requested an interview with my investigators so we can reopen the case.’

Dale said schools need more training to spot human trafficking, which has begun hotels, airports, bus stations, and any other hot spots for the crime.

‘She was a victim and somehow her cries fell through the cracks and I think that’s why it’s so imperative that we get the schools involved,’ Dale said.
